crossroad.title: A different path
crossroad.p1: I was a welder for several years. The heat of the workshop, the mask, the smell of metal. A physical, hands-on trade where a lack of precision doesn't forgive.
crossroad.p2: But at some point, I needed something else. The feeling of having reached a plateau, of no longer learning. I wanted to challenge myself again, to turn toward a more intellectual field. The idea matured over time.
crossroad.p3: In 2017, the opportunity came. I started from scratch and trained in software development.

building.title: Building differently
building.p1: Today, I still shape things. Web applications, deployment pipelines, infrastructure. The craft has changed, but not the standards.
building.p2: What I love about this job is that you never stop learning. Every project brings new challenges, new solutions to implement. Comfort doesn't exist — and that's exactly what I was looking for.
building.p3: A bad weld breaks. Poorly thought-out code does too, but later, more insidiously. The attention to detail remains the same.
building.p4: I believe in well-made web. Accessible, so everyone can use it. Lean, to avoid wasting resources unnecessarily. Clean code, lightweight pages, measured impact — that's also what being a developer craftsman means.

transmit.title: Giving back
transmit.p1: When I started, the community helped me. Today, I try to return the favor.
transmit.p2: I mentor junior developers. Two of them are now employed. I've also given a talk to share my knowledge.

breathe.title: Breathe
breathe.p1: To disconnect, there's the mountains, the starry sky, the camera. Another way to frame the world.

next.title: What's next
next.p1: The best collaborations often start with a first conversation.
